Mathematical Foundation

Notation Rules and Algebra with Vectors and Tensors

In the mathematical formulation of quantities and fields, there are two types of notation which we shall use throughout the book: symbolic (or Gibbs’) notation as well as index notation. For the sake of convenience and to provide suitably abstract formulations, we mostly prefer the symbolic notation. Let \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\) be vectors in a (real) space of dimension \(D\).

\[\begin{split}\boldsymbol{a} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\ a_2 \\ \vdots \\ a_D \end{pmatrix} = a_i, \quad \boldsymbol{b} = \begin{pmatrix} b_1 \\ b_2 \\ \vdots \\ b_D \end{pmatrix} = b_i \quad (1 \leq i \leq D)\end{split}\]

For the scalar (or dot) product:

\[\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{b} = a_i b_i \quad (1 \leq i \leq D)\]

Using Einstein’s summation convention:

\[a_i b_i = \sum_{i=1}^D a_i b_i,\]

where repeated indices are summed.

For the vector (or cross) product:

\[\begin{split}\boldsymbol{a} \times \boldsymbol{b} = \varepsilon_{ijk} a_i b_j \boldsymbol{e}_k = \operatorname{det}\begin{pmatrix} a_1 & a_2 & \ldots & a_D \\ b_1 & b_2 & \ldots & b_D \\ \boldsymbol{e}_1 & \boldsymbol{e}_2 & \ldots & \boldsymbol{e}_D \end{pmatrix} \quad (1 \leq i, j, k \leq D),\end{split}\]

where \(\varepsilon_{ijk}\) is the permutation symbol (also known as the Levi-Civita tensor \(\varepsilon\)), and \(e_i (1 \leq i \leq D)\) are base vectors:

\[\begin{split}e_1 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ \vdots \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad e_2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ \vdots \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad \ldots, \quad e_D = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ \vdots \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

The dot product of base vectors is given by:

\[e_i \cdot e_j = \delta = \delta_{ij},\]

where \(\delta\) is the Kronecker symbol (unit or identity matrix):

\[\begin{split}\delta = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & \cdots & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & \cdots & 1 \end{pmatrix}, \quad \delta_{ij} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{when } i = j, \\ 0 & \text{when } i \neq j. \end{cases}\end{split}\]

For the dyadic (or tensor) product:

\[\begin{split}\boldsymbol{a} \otimes \boldsymbol{b} = a_i b_j = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 b_1 & a_1 b_2 & \cdots & a_1 b_D \\ a_2 b_1 & a_2 b_2 & \cdots & a_2 b_D \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_D b_1 & a_D b_2 & \cdots & a_D b_D \end{pmatrix} \quad (1 \leq i, j \leq D).\end{split}\]

This results in a second-order tensor \(A = a \otimes b\). Often, the multiplication symbol is omitted, and the tensor product is simply denoted as \(\boldsymbol{A} = \boldsymbol{ab}\).

The components \(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_D\) of \(\boldsymbol{a}\) can also be expressed via summation:

\[\boldsymbol{a} = a_i \boldsymbol{e}_i \quad (1 \leq i \leq D).\]

The magnitude (or norm) of a vector \(\boldsymbol{a}\) is given by:

\[\|\boldsymbol{a}\| = \sqrt{\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{a}} = \sqrt{a_i a_i}.\]

If \(\|\boldsymbol{a}\| = 1\), the vector is called a unit vector, e.g., \(\boldsymbol{e}_i\). The normalized vector of \(\boldsymbol{a}\) is:

\[\hat{\boldsymbol{a}} = \frac{\boldsymbol{a}}{\|\boldsymbol{a}\|} = \frac{a_i}{\sqrt{a_j a_j}} e_i.\]

It can be verified that \(\hat{\boldsymbol{a}}\) is itself a unit vector since \(\|\hat{\boldsymbol{a}}\| = 1\).

Relations for Scalar and Vector Products

If \(\hat{\boldsymbol{a}}\) and \(\hat{\boldsymbol{b}}\) are unit vectors in the directions of \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\), respectively, then:

\[\hat{\boldsymbol{a}} \cdot \hat{\boldsymbol{b}} = \cos \theta,\]

where \(\theta\) represents the angle between the two directions.

For vectors \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\):

\[\boldsymbol{a} = \|\boldsymbol{a}\| \hat{\boldsymbol{a}}, \quad \boldsymbol{b} = \|\boldsymbol{b}\| \hat{\boldsymbol{b}}.\]

The scalar product becomes:

\[\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{b} = \|\boldsymbol{a}\| \|\boldsymbol{b}\| \cos \theta.\]

Projection of a Vector

To project \(\boldsymbol{b}\) onto the unit vector \(\hat{\boldsymbol{a}}\):

\[\|\boldsymbol{c}\| = \|\boldsymbol{b}\| \cos \theta = \hat{\boldsymbol{a}} \cdot \boldsymbol{b} = \frac{\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{b}}{\|\boldsymbol{a}\|}.\]

If the angle \(\theta\) between the two vectors is a right angle (\(\theta = \pi/2\)), then \(\cos \theta = 0\). Such vectors are orthogonal, and the condition for orthogonality is:

\[\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{b} = 0.\]

Cross Product

The cross product \(\boldsymbol{a} \times \boldsymbol{b}\) forms a vector normal to the plane defined by \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\):

\[\boldsymbol{a} \times \boldsymbol{b} = \|\boldsymbol{a}\| \|\boldsymbol{b}\| \sin \theta \hat{\boldsymbol{n}},\]

where \(\hat{\boldsymbol{n}}\) is a unit vector normal to the plane of \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\). The magnitude \(\|\boldsymbol{a} \times \boldsymbol{b}\|\) is the area of the parallelogram spanned by the vectors.

Coordinate System and Spatial Vector

To describe physical objects in space and define their motion, we use the \(D\)-dimensional Euclidean space \(\Re^D (D=1,2,3)\).

Position Vector

In an orthogonal Cartesian coordinate system:

\[\begin{split}\boldsymbol{x} = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{in } \Re^3 (3D).\end{split}\]

For \(\Re^2 (2D)\):

\[\boldsymbol{x}^T = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 & x_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x & y \end{pmatrix}.\]

For \(\Re^1 (1D)\):

\[\boldsymbol{x}^T = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \end{pmatrix}.\]

Gradient Operator in Cylindrical Coordinates

The gradient operator is written as:

\[\begin{split}\nabla = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial}{\partial r} \\ \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

If \(\boldsymbol{a}\) is a vector in cylindrical coordinates \(\boldsymbol{a}^T = \begin{pmatrix} a_r & a_\phi & a_z \end{pmatrix}\), then the scalar product \(\nabla \cdot \boldsymbol{a}\) becomes:

\[\nabla \cdot \boldsymbol{a} = \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial (r a_r)}{\partial r} + \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial a_\phi}{\partial \phi} + \frac{\partial a_z}{\partial z}.\]

Curl in Cylindrical Coordinates

The curl of \(\boldsymbol{a}\) in cylindrical coordinates is:

\[\begin{split}\nabla \times \boldsymbol{a} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial a_z}{\partial \phi} - \frac{\partial a_\phi}{\partial z} \\ \frac{\partial a_r}{\partial z} - \frac{\partial a_z}{\partial r} \\ \frac{1}{r} \left( \frac{\partial}{\partial r} (r a_\phi) - \frac{\partial a_r}{\partial \phi} \right) \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

Symmetric and Antisymmetric Tensors

A second-order tensor \(\boldsymbol{A} = A_{ij}\) is symmetric if:

\[\boldsymbol{A} = \boldsymbol{A}^T \quad \text{or} \quad A_{ij} = A_{ji}.\]

Any tensor \(\boldsymbol{A}\) can be written as the sum of symmetric and antisymmetric parts:

\[\boldsymbol{A} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \boldsymbol{A} + \boldsymbol{A}^T \right) + \frac{1}{2} \left( \boldsymbol{A} - \boldsymbol{A}^T \right),\]

where:

\[\boldsymbol{B}_s = \frac{1}{2} \left( \boldsymbol{A} + \boldsymbol{A}^T \right), \quad \boldsymbol{B}_a = \frac{1}{2} \left( \boldsymbol{A} - \boldsymbol{A}^T \right).\]

Tensor and Vector Products

The scalar product of a tensor \(\boldsymbol{A}\) with a vector \(\boldsymbol{a}\) is:

\[\boldsymbol{A} \cdot \boldsymbol{a} = \sum_i^D \boldsymbol{e}_i \sum_j^D A_{ij} a_j.\]

Conversely, the scalar product of a vector \(\boldsymbol{a}\) with a tensor \(\boldsymbol{A}\) is:

\[\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{A} = \sum_i^D \boldsymbol{e}_i \sum_j^D a_j A_{ji}.\]

A tensor \(\boldsymbol{A}\) is diagonal if all off-diagonal components are zero, i.e., \(A_{ij} = 0\) for \(i \neq j\):

\[\begin{split}\boldsymbol{A} = \begin{pmatrix} A_{11} & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & A_{22} & \cdots & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & \cdots & A_{DD} \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

Diagonal tensors are always symmetric.

Scalar and Vector Projections

If \(\hat{\boldsymbol{a}}\) and \(\hat{\boldsymbol{b}}\) are unit vectors, then:

\[\hat{\boldsymbol{a}} \cdot \hat{\boldsymbol{b}} = \cos \theta,\]

where \(\theta\) is the angle between the two directions. For vectors \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\), we find the scalar product:

\[\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{b} = \|\boldsymbol{a}\| \|\boldsymbol{b}\| \cos \theta.\]

Orthogonality

Vectors are orthogonal if their scalar product is zero:

\[\boldsymbol{a} \cdot \boldsymbol{b} = 0 \quad \text{when } \theta = \frac{\pi}{2}.\]

Cross Product

The cross product \(\boldsymbol{a} \times \boldsymbol{b}\) forms a vector normal to the plane of \(\boldsymbol{a}\) and \(\boldsymbol{b}\):

\[\boldsymbol{a} \times \boldsymbol{b} = \|\boldsymbol{a}\| \|\boldsymbol{b}\| \sin \theta \hat{\boldsymbol{n}},\]

where \(\hat{\boldsymbol{n}}\) is a unit vector perpendicular to the plane.

Coordinate Transformation in Euclidean Space

To represent spatial motion and positioning, we use the \(D\)-dimensional Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^D\). A position vector in \(3D\) is written as:

\[\begin{split}\boldsymbol{x} = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

For \(2D\) and \(1D\), the coordinates are given as:

\[\boldsymbol{x}^T = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 & x_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x & y \end{pmatrix}, \quad \boldsymbol{x}^T = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} x \end{pmatrix}.\]

Gradient Operator

In cylindrical coordinates, the gradient operator is:

\[\begin{split}\nabla = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial}{\partial r} \\ \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]

Divergence and Curl

For the divergence in cylindrical coordinates:

\[\nabla \cdot \boldsymbol{a} = \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial (r a_r)}{\partial r} + \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial a_\phi}{\partial \phi} + \frac{\partial a_z}{\partial z}.\]

For the curl in cylindrical coordinates:

\[\begin{split}\nabla \times \boldsymbol{a} = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{1}{r} \frac{\partial a_z}{\partial \phi} - \frac{\partial a_\phi}{\partial z} \\ \frac{\partial a_r}{\partial z} - \frac{\partial a_z}{\partial r} \\ \frac{1}{r} \left( \frac{\partial}{\partial r} (r a_\phi) - \frac{\partial a_r}{\partial \phi} \right) \end{pmatrix}.\end{split}\]
